issues.description: The problem statement uses two different names for the same animal feeding method: the UML and many parts refer to messageOnFeed(), while several textual instructions (for Seal/Pig/Goat behavior and feedAllAnimals) refer to getFeedingSound(). This mismatch in method name across the specification will confuse students about which method to implement and which method to call (e.g., in Farm.feedAllAnimals() and in singFarmSongVerse). The solution implements messageOnFeed(), so following the getFeedingSound() wording from the text could lead students to implement the wrong method name or be unsure which name is required.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the method name across the problem statement, template, and solution. Either (A) change all occurrences of getFeedingSound() in the problem text to messageOnFeed(), or (B) rename the abstract method in Animal (and its implementations) to getFeedingSound(). Update the Farm description (feedAllAnimals and singFarmSong instructions) to call the chosen method name. This keeps the UML, textual instructions, template TODOs, and solution consistent.

issues.description: The problem statement refers to the feeding-sound method using two different identifiers: messageOnFeed() (in the UML and Part 1 instructions) and getFeedingSound() (in the concrete animal tasks and feedAllAnimals description). The template/solution code uses messageOnFeed() as the abstract/implemented method. This inconsistent naming for the same concept (the animal feeding-sound method) can confuse students about which method to implement and which method the Farm should call.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the feeding-sound method name consistent across all artifacts. Since the template/solution use messageOnFeed(), update the problem statement occurrences of getFeedingSound() (and any other references) to messageOnFeed(). Alternatively, if preferring getFeedingSound(), rename the abstract method and all implementations in the template/solution to getFeedingSound(), but preserve a single name everywhere to avoid student confusion.
